awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Understanding Cultural Influences On Population Structure and History through Genetic Analyses of Assyrians
awd_abstract_narration:
Understanding the cultural and behavioral factors that shape human populations is important for studying the complex history and modern day distribution of our species. Language, religion, geopolitical boundaries, and sociocultural pressures are four such factors, but it is often difficult to explore their effects on population structure within a single population. This study explores the population genetics of present-day Assyrians, a Near Eastern ethnoreligious minority. Due to their relative isolation since the Sassanid Era, Assyrians are an excellent population for understanding the effects of linguistic, religious, and sociopolitical boundaries on populations, and for reconstructing the population history of Mesopotamia, an area of exceptional importance for the study of prehistoric and historic human migrations, the spread of agriculture, and the advent of modern civilization. The project will also bring attention to Assyrians as one of the fastest-growing underrepresented communities in the United States, introduce members of the Assyrian community to anthropological genetics and anthropology, and support the professional development of a graduate student who is also a member of this community.
 
During this 12-month project, the investigators will determine mitochondrial and Y-chromosome haplotypes for at least 140 unrelated Assyrian individuals in the United States, mainly from Chicago area, home of the largest Assyrian population (n=80,000) outside of the Near East. Various genetic analytic methods will be used to measure differences in haplotype distributions among Assyrians originating from different countries (geopolitical boundaries), and between Assyrians and other Near Eastern populations (language, religious, and social boundaries). The project has the potential to significantly advance generalizable knowledge in human population genetics, in addition to filling in gaps in the population history of an individual culture and a historically important region of the world. Results will be disseminated through professional presentations and journals, but also through public outreach within and beyond the Assyrian community.

por.por_cntn:
This project provided a profile of maternal and paternal genetic lineages of Assyrian population. Thanks to participating Assyrians from across the United States (Yonkers, NY, New Britain, CT, and numerous cities in California, Illinois, Michigan, and Arizona), we were able to collect samples for genetic analysis from individuals coming from a wide range of historically Assyrian villages and towns spanning across the Hakkari and Tur Abdin Mountains, the Mosul/Nineveh Plains, and the Urmia region. The results of our study show that a majority of Assyrians represent maternal and paternal lineages (identified by mitochondrial and Y-chromosome DNA, respectively) known to have originated in Mesopotamia and South Caucasus. Most of the rest of the Assyrian lineages were of Near Eastern origin. The maternal lineages of the Assyrians that participated in this project did not show any links to sub-Saharan African or East/North Asian peoples. That is while most other populations of the region possess sub-Saharan African, and North or East Asian lineages at low frequencies. By determining the complete sequences of mitochondrial DNA for Assyrian participants, we were also able to identify several new maternal lineages not previously reported in any genetic studies. Our Assyrian paternal lineages results showed a very strong Mesopotamian character, indicated by some of the highest frequencies reported for lineages known as haplogroups T and J1xPage08.

Assyrians are one of the few ethnoreligious minority populations of the Near East whose identities and traditions link them to pre-Islamic, and sometimes, pre-Christianity populations. Due to relative isolation throughout their long histories, studying these populations provides unique insights into the population genetics of a region that is on crossroads of the Old World. Therefore, the results of this project provided knowledge essential to better understanding the prehistoric and historic movements and interactions of the human populations in this region. Furthermore, Assyrians are the largest population that speaks an Aramaic language, so the results of this project fill an important gap in the genetic studies of the Semitic-speaking populations.

Starting over a century ago with the Assyrian Genocide, the Assyrian population has suffered from forced displacement, resulting in a large diaspora into the West. The ongoing conflict and war since the 2003 invasion of Iraq, and more recently, the rise of ISIS in Iraq and Syria, has accelerated the diaspora of the Assyrian population away from their homeland. We hope that this project will bring attention to Assyrians as one of the fastest growing underrepresented communities in the United States. Moreover, with the situation worsening in Iraq and Syria, this research will hopefully alert researchers from across academia to the problems faced by both native and diasporic Assyrian communities.
